Review of T-Mobile Home Internet 15-Day Test DriveService Start: I began the 15-day trial with T-Mobile Home Internet in November. Initially, the service was poor, but after some adjustments, it significantly improved. I was impressed with the speed and quality of the service, to the point where I considered switching my lines from Xfinity to T-Mobile. However, due to the complexity of the process, I decided to cancel.Cancellation Process: I spoke with customer service, and they recommended canceling within the 15-day period, which I did. I received a return label for the equipment and sent it back before the deadline.Subsequent Issues: On November 29, I received a letter from the collections department for $55 with no explanation. I never received a bill from T-Mobile for this amount. Then, on December 9, 2024, I received another letter from a collection agency in PA for the same $55. Finally, on December 14, I received a bill for $32.66 for internet usage, despite having returned the equipment on time.Reflection: I am referring this case to the consumer protection department in the state of Oregon for review. It is concerning that a large company like T-Mobile uses tactics like these without following proper procedures. I hope that with advances in artificial intelligence, new companies with better services and more transparent practices will emerge, eliminating the need to deal with situations like this.

We had T-Mobile internet service for 19 months.  The T-Mobile service at the beginning was pretty good, with the service freezing needing a restart only about once a week. However, the towards the end in August of 2023, the gateway(modem) needed to be restarted several times a day in order to function. Around the same time T-Mobile removed the $5 discount for auto pay if you were using a credit card. Something they had allowed for over a year. On Aug 23rd we ordered Xfinity. The Xfinity gateway would be delivered in several days. On Aug 24th, 2023 I called customer service and told them I wished to cancel. However, customer service said I needed to try a new gateway first to see if that would correct the problem. I figured I would compare them both. T-Mobile sent a replacement quickly, but it did not do much better with Mbps download of 44.  The Xfinity gateway came a few days later with Mbps in the 400's for downloads without any problems. I canceled T-Mobile service on Sept 2, 23 through their customer service. When canceling they requested the 6 digit number that I gave them when I signed up 19 months earlier.  I gave them the number I had written down in my T-Mobile file. The customer service rep said it was the wrong number. I said that is the one I uses. They said it was imperative that I give them the 6-digit code.  I asked if they could use my soc sec number or email me a reset and they said no. They said that I would have to physically go to a T-Mobile store and request my 6-digit number after they verified my identity.  I drove to the nearest store located at 2024 IL-50 Ste A1, Bourbonnais IL 60914 and spoke with a rep named Michael.  He said he could not give me the 6-digit number and told me to call customer service back and tell them so. I went home and called and told them what he said, and they said okay and that they would email a return label for the gateway.  I received the email with the label on September 2nd, 2023 and returned the gateway to UPS. T-Mobile received the gateway on Sept 11 23.  I received a letter stating that "They received the gateway, and no further action is needed on your part." Then on Sept 19, 23 T-Mobile collected an auto pay of $55 from my credit card on file.  I called my credit card to dispute the charge.  T-Mobile sent me a new bill asking for the $55, plus $25 for a chargeback, Plus the next months $55 for a total of $135.  I called customer service on Oct 7, 23, and they said I needed to go to an actual store because they could not help me again because of the 6-digit pin saying the one I gave them was incorrect. I went to the store in Bradley Il and they told me that the account had never been canceled, even though customer service sent the return label and had received the gateway. The store contacted T-mobile customer service from their store and eventually a very rude corporate manager named Patrick said that they insisted I pay the full $135.  I explained I had cancelled the service on Sept 2, 23 and returned the gateway.  He said it was T-Mobiles' policy to have you also physically come to the store to cancel and that it wasn't officially canceled until that day which was over a month later. I told him I physically went to the T-Mobile store but Michael would not give me the pin.  He scolded me saying I should have used the phrase "I wish to have you cancel my account" I explained that I had already done that with customer service rep on the phone and that I had told Michael that I needed the pin number for them to cancel it. Patrick from Corporate says that I am repeating myself and it was my fault for not saying that I wanted Michael to cancel the account.  He then said that he would offer me a one-time deal that he would forgive the last months charge and that he was being very gracious in doing so.  I again told him I didn't even have a gateway to use the service and that T-Mobile had it after sending me the return email and label. He again said it was never fully canceled to their satisfaction whatever that means.  We went round and round until I said I would pay $55 for the month I disputed even though I had canceled the service just to end the madness. He said he also insisted on the $25. I said no and that I wanted to only pay $55 only on that day.  He said it would cost an additional $10 to have an operator take my payment.  I asked if I could do it online without a charge and he said yes but it would not give me a confirmation.  Because he was not helpful at all we ended the call.  I went home and paid $55 online and still received a confirmation number. It seemed that Patrick was trying to squeeze even more money from me. The amount of time and effort I have put into resolving this is ridicules. There appears to be no training for customer service either at the store level or at corporate.Update 10/15/23  T-Mobile reached out and we reached a mutual understanding.

Although Samsung boasts waterproof/resistant, it is not dustproof. Amazing that a speck of dust can create havoc on the screen rendering it unreadable at a significant pace and hence I had to replace it after 7(?) months or so‚Ä¶while I had insurance on all my devices had to shell out another 700.00+ to get the replacement. Ok, lesson learned, be sure to create a good seal around the folding part.In May of 2024  (with another 18 months of installment payments left), Wi-Fi and Bluetooth stopped working entirely and despite many attempts and online research to fix on my own, had no other choice but to get a replacement phone. I  did not want to deal with a claim at the time due to the frustration of already having to replace again and of course work and life. Went back to the AT&T store and explained the situation and wound up with a new phone and a new business line I did not need, it was not clear to me that although I brought the old phone in  at the time that I would be  stuck with paying installments on both. Again, I was not paying attention as the frustration just grew ‚Äì especially after there happened to be a Samsung rep in the store and when the sales person asked him if it was common that the Wi-Fi and Bluetooth would stop working and he shook his head rather non-chalantly and that is when I popped up and advised that is not what I discovered in various online sites ‚Äì Samsung for one - regarding a known issue with the fold.Once I discovered I am still paying for the Fold, I called AT&T and an hour of wasted effort, I was referred to the claim site and here is where it gets really interesting. The Fold no longer showed up as a registered device so I could not file a claim‚Ä¶ AT&T rep on the phone had me register the phone with my true number associated and I asked if that was going to impact my current working phone and basically had me attempt to claim on both phones‚Ä¶ I can‚Äôt make this stuff up folks, simply unreal. I then went back to the store to see if the claim can be done from there and was told of course they could help. Only issue is the phone had been turned off for a bit so now it was not showing up on the network and when I asked how to do that as the phone did not work‚Ä¶ no Wi-Fi ‚Äì the salesperson asked her co-worker and he would not even respond to me which is ok, but stated to put a sim in the phone and make a few calls, etc‚Ä¶Went home and tried it and guess what? The main complaint I have with Vodafone UK is their poor service, specifically regarding buffering and latency issues. After months of frustration, I bought a third-party router (TP-Link Deco) which finally resolved the issues, proving that the fault was with the router provided by Vodafone. Despite this, Vodafone refused to send a replacement router or send someone to test the equipment. Their boosters and routers are of very poor quality, and I strongly recommend avoiding them. Instead, invest in a reliable router like TP-Link Deco or Eero and use the PPPoE account provided by Vodafone rather than their subpar devices.From the outset, Vodafone‚Äôs service has been appalling. When I first signed up, they never bothered to send anyone to properly set up the connection. Aside from the Openreach engineer installing the fibre, I had to do everything else myself. Despite reporting multiple issues, Vodafone repeatedly came up with different excuses for the poor service. At various times, they blamed congestion, my house, the number of devices I was using, or even the fact that I tested the internet on iPhones rather than Android devices. I was told to make video calls to show the cable I was using‚Äîeven though I was using a high-quality Cat 8 cable.Despite all of this, no one from Vodafone ever came to my address to properly investigate the issue. Instead, I was left dealing with a support team that appeared to lack any knowledge of broadband or technical troubleshooting. I‚Äôve had to waste hours on the phone, often during the day when I‚Äôm at work, and was still left with no resolution.Even after I reported the case to CISAS, Vodafone continued to be inconsistent. They emailed me stating I would not have to pay a termination fee, yet every time I tried to cancel, they insisted I would be charged ¬£70 for the remaining three months. This lack of accountability is unacceptable.To make matters worse, when I asked for email responses instead of phone calls, their standard reply was to offer another 24-month contract, with no credit or reimbursement for the time I paid for non-functional devices.For anyone considering Vodafone broadband, I strongly advise against it. If you‚Äôre looking for a reliable provider, check out Zen, Cuckoo, or Utility Warehouse, and focus on Openreach providers with better reviews. Avoid Vodafone‚Äôs devices entirely‚Äîuse your own router with a PPPoE account, which is easy to set up and far more reliable.Additional Advice: If you‚Äôre considering Wi-Fi 6E or Wi-Fi 7, make sure you have the latest devices in your home (e.g., iPhone 16, the latest MacBook, or top-tier Lenovo laptops) to fully utilise these technologies. Otherwise, they‚Äôre not worth it.To Vodafone: Please do not respond with a generic ‚Äúcontact us to discuss‚Äù reply. Every time I‚Äôve contacted you, I‚Äôve been stonewalled, ignored, or offered unhelpful solutions. Your customer service is the worst I‚Äôve ever experienced.Update 13.01.25: Vodafone reached an agreement, and I received a credit as compensation. A new contract has been established without any additional boosters, offering a favourable monthly rate.

However, whilst I called, they also tried two hard resets of the Power Hub, which had no success, so all I could do was wait for the magic to happen overnight. The following day, the Power Hub was still flashing red, and no connection occurred. Customer support contacted me to double-check if everything was up and running by now. I had to deny it. They tried another hard reset and then asked me to send in several photos of my setup. I would be contacted within hours by the specialist team, and if they could not solve the issue, a technical engineer would be appointed for a home visit. Nothing happened. I gave them another call. They were still waiting for the photos to be uploaded/attached to the ticket this could take another 16 hours as these photos are usually only uploaded around 9 am every day... (WHAT?) The next day, nothing happened, although I was supposed to get a follow-up call between 1 and 3 pm. Called at 3 pm, and still no photos, if I could send them again. Did so, but this time, I insisted on staying on the call until I received confirmation that the images were attached to the ticket. This happened, and I was told the specialist team would now be in touch within 4 hours. After 2 hours, att 6 pm last night, I got a text from the specialist team that an internal team would not look into my fault and that it could take until today for an update to be provided. The customer support employee from last night promised me a call this morning, which unfortunately did not happen. Instead, I got my first bill claiming money for the service that is supposedly been running smoothly since Monday and although I had been promised that I would only be charged from when the connection is succesfully established and I would be entitled to compensation as well. So, I had to call myself at noon to challenge the bill and now learn that the internal team had now promised "an update" on the case on the next day. So, since Monday, I am without any internet connection at home and I can no longer believe that anyone is actually really trying hard to solve the issue, instead of having two separate working lines with two different providers, I now have zero working lines and feel utterly neglected and only promised loose, non-binding updates. Where is the service technician at my place that was promised to me on Tuesday? To avoid similar issues, at this stage, I can only recommend avoiding this company by any means.

A falling branch knocked down the fibre line near my property on the 24th November. I reported the fault immediately to the customer service team. It is now 16th December. I have made ten calls to the customer service team, had seven different Openreach engineers visit, been given three different dates to put the cable back up and still the cable has not been reconnected. The first engineer told me that a pole might need to be replaced but a temporary repair could be done in the meantime and would take about an hour. Still the cable has not been reconnected. We are pensioners living in rural Wales and rely heavily on this service as our telephone is VOIP and therefore not working either. Our mobile service is patchy at best and we are concerned that we are now facing Christmas unable to connect with family and friends. The customer service approach is hamstrung by adherence to script and distance from the problem and despite escalating the complaint to a manager we have made no headway whatsoever. I am sick and tired of being told how sorry everybody is for these are just words to dismiss me when what is needed is action to remedy the problem. This level of customer service is deplorable for a global company and I will certainly consider my options when contract renewal is due.I am writing an update to my review having seen the reply from Vodafone. If the respondent had read the review more carefully I made it clear that the fault was reported on 24th November. Storm Darragh occurred on 7th December. That gave a window of two clear working weeks to take action and rectify the problem. Even if a specialist team was needed to put in a new pole, a temporary repair could have been effected to keep us online and this opportunity was not followed up. I have now had four dates promised and passed and I still have no internet or phone. The call count to the customer service line is now up to thirteen and a total of seven hours spent trying to get an answer to this problem. All I keep hearing is "we are waiting for an update from Openreach". I have escalated the complaint once again and am now told that someone will be in touch within the next seven days. I cannot help but reflect that if my monthly direct debit had been refused the action would have been far more swift and robust. This whole episode is an absolute masterclass in how to irritate and alienate paying customers who rely on a service which is not being provided. Maybe if the customer service was more focused it would not be necessary to have a team monitoring social media to deflect and excuse poor reviews.

I ordered Full Fibre broadband, which required both external and internal installations. The external work was completed in preparation for the installation inside my flat, initially scheduled for Friday, 8th November 2024.1) On Tuesday, 5th November 2024, at 15:36, I received a text from Vodafone informing me that both my order and the engineer appointment had been cancelled.2) Upon investigation, I learned that a neighbour had lodged a complaint about a City Fibre engineer allegedly using an unauthorised key to access the building. My neighbour confirmed that his complaint was solely about the key-cutting incident and did not pertain to the work itself.4) Vodafone misunderstood or mismanaged this request and cancelled my order without contacting me for clarification.5) I contacted City Fibre, who confirmed they never requested the cancellation. They read their notes verbatim, with timestamps, and reiterated that they needed Vodafone's instruction to proceed.**From my perspective, the solution was straightforward. The City Fibre engineer had already completed the initial phase of the installation and only needed to complete the work in my flat. All that was needed was for Vodafone to contact City Fibre to confirm that no neighbour requested the work to stop. However, Vodafone chose not to take these steps, even though I had arranged time off work for the installation on 8th November 2024.**---Over two days, I spent countless hours calling Vodafone, navigating automated systems and speaking to service advisors who told me they could not reverse the cancellation or directly contact City Fibre. Vodafone repeatedly blamed City Fibre, while City Fibre stated they could only act on Vodafone's instructions. This lack of transparency and ownership left me in the middle, managing the coordination myself.**Additional Frustrations**- Service advisors directed me to place a new order on the website, which I did, only for it to be cancelled again at 11:26 on Wednesday, 6th November 2024.- Most service advisors refused to transfer me to the "home broadband" team until one agent eventually did. This agent promised to expedite the issue with City Fibre and follow up with a call between 17:30 and 18:30 the next evening but failed to do so.- I had to contact Vodafone again, and after extensive discussions, an advisor escalated the issue but could not connect me to a manager, resulting in another 24-hour wait for a callback.- A manager called on Thursday, 7th November 2024, only to inform me that their only option was to raise another formal complaint, adding another day to the process.- Shaiana from customer care called the following day, not to discuss my complaint but only to transfer me back to the "home broadband" team, where a third order was placed over the phone, which was subsequently cancelled on Tuesday, 12th November 2024.**Update**I have been contacted by Vodafone Customer Care, who advised that "City Fibre requires up to 120 days to obtain permission" to complete the work. However, the agent was unable to clarify what specific permission is needed. This statement directly contradicts City Fibre, who have already completed the initial phase of the installation and were scheduled to finish the work within my flat.Vodafone has also confirmed that they cannot provide interim broadband and no longer offer broadband services that are not Full Fibre. As I cannot wait 120 days without an internet service provider, Vodafone has effectively left me with no choice but to take my business elsewhere.

When AT&T advertises a "Buy One-Get One" deal - buyer beware! NOTHING is free with AT&T!My BOGO deal was a "free" iPhone 7 when purchasing (signing a contract for) an iPhone 7+. After the purchase, I noticed a recurring credit of $21 on my bill. I thought it was because of certain discounts I get for membership in an organization AT&T honors, so I didn't pay much attention to the credit.Later, when I was able to pay off all my mobile devices, I noticed my bill had increased over $300! After arguing with the customer service rep, I was informed that AT&T had expected me to continue the installment payment plan for the iPhone 7+ for 30 months. But because I paid the balance for the installment plan after only 17 months, I was now liable for the remaining balance for the "BOGO" iPhone 7. I was INCREDULOUS!When I objected, the lady told me that I was informed this would happen at the time I paid off the balance. However I was never informed and told the customer service rep that if they wanted the $300 for the "free" phone they should take it out of the other rep's paycheck because he failed to inform me of the consequences of paying off the balance of the installment plan.Of course, she said they couldn't do that. So I demanded that AT&T should absorb the $300 because it's a misunderstanding and, after all, I've been a loyal customer for 25 years and it would be good customer relations. I said if AT&T would do this, I would make my satisfaction known publicly through Social Media. However, if AT&T failed to handle this in my favor, I said I would take that experience public on Social Media as well.The customer service rep paused for a moment, put me on hold, and voila! When she reconnected with me she said they had worked out a deal for me. If I "technically" put the iPhone 7 BACK on an "installment plan," they could continue the monthly $21 credit until the balance of the installment plan was paid, with nothing coming out of my pocket! I agreed to this compromise, and AT&T has held up their end of the bargain. So, AT&T is now paying for their own "free" BOGO phone again.This issue was, indeed, resolved to my satisfaction, and ALL of the 3 service reps I spoke with were courteous, friendly, and competent.But remember, AT&T + BOGO = Buyer Beware!! Nothing is "free" with AT&T.

Of course I do. I was a telecoms software engineer for many years including mobile. The reason why the calls now drop out is because in this area, 3 have removed a number of older transmitters replacing them with fewer 4G/5G transmitters resulting in more fringe areas (grey spots) until they start to backfill. I live in a small market town close to a major new city and not some rural back area. A similar and well documented situation existed when t-mobile merged with Orange to become EE and EE removed far more duplicate transmitters that they should have done basing this on computer modelling coverage rather than actual real world coverage. OFCOM became involved and EE had to fix it.  Going back to idmobile and 3 , I am expecting (and hope) this call drop out problem to substantially reduce once 5G covers this area. Or more to the point, 3 commission the currently idle masts. Having said all that, I was a direct customer of 3 for many, many years but moved to idmobile roughly for the same price. Idmobile have a far superior and easy to use website, data-rollover, and inclusive international roaming covering much of the world that 3 used to cover. I have no intention of cancelling my idmobile contract.

This review relates to the refer a friend scheme only, overall with the rest of the ID mobile,  I've had no problems.The refer a friend scheme seems designed to make sure you don't get the referral monies, unless you have the time and persistence. It starts well that you get a link to use to instigate the referral. Other companies then use this link to track and pay the bonus, but not ID mobile.The first step is the referred person needs to make contact to enter the  account number within 14 days. (Hurdle 1)Then you need to remember 90 days later that you referred someone as the money is not credited automatically. If you manage to remember then after a live chat your be told that the other person, either the referrer or referee needs to make contact first as well.  (Hurdle 2).The other person then makes contact and that seems to unlock some blocker on the referee account. (Hurdle 3).Then the referee has to make contact again to again request the bonus is paid (Hurdle 4).You are then told that for the other person to get their bonus they have to make contact again. (Hurdle 5).If you have read this review to this point - you are probably someone who might get the bonus, you have persistence!I queried the process and was sent terms and conditions of the scheme, it may say that you have to take all these steps (it just feels like they are there to thwart issuing the bonus), but in summary won't be referring anyone else - the process is just unnecessarily too time consuming and complicated.

My overall experience with O2 has been mixed. There is no other way to describe it.Let's start off with the positives.I have what I would call an unbeatable deal from O2 thanks to the Virgin Mobile migration. My phone bill is ¬£6.79/mo for completely unlimited data (on VM, it was for 2GB, plan price was originally 2GB for a 12 month contract in 08/2018), which no other network would ever be able to beat. I currently use around 40GB in a month, which is a stark contrast to never using over 4GB in a month for 5 years. Granted my usage habits have changed now that I'm free to burn my data.Through the Virgin Mobile migration, I also gained the ability to use 4G calling and WiFi calling (yes Virgin did have the ability for both, but it just would have been a pain to set up) from the moment I migrated. Unfortunately, these features did disappear for a long time (from about July to mid-December) which sucks. I don't make calls often but both options make calls crystal clear and reliable.A bit after mid-November, I decided to get a SIM swap with O2, since I was still using my old Virgin SIM (which was originally programmed to connect to the EE network, still have remnants of that even with my new O2 SIM with the T-Mobile MNC seemingly reporting "Virgin Mobile" when manually searching for networks). The SIM swap processed extremely quickly with being delivered within just 2 days (one day after my order confirmation), which was a stark contrast from the experience that I had with moving someone from Plusnet to EE (SIM took 4 days to deliver and EE didn't even send confirmation details).Priority is a cool plus to have and getting Volt features is nice too.Now the negatives.With the migration, I was promised the visual voicemail feature on my Android phone, but it has yet to work for me. I've had a tab for it appear once, but that's it.On Virgin, RCS always worked perfectly fine. Meanwhile on O2, I've had a few problems (particularly by the migration from O2's RCS to Jibe RCS) and it's left me unable to use RCS.I'd like to finally end this off with a concern I have for the future as an O2 customer. Due to the way that O2 migrated Virgin customers, my tariff price is ¬£13.29 with a ¬£6.50 discount bolt-on. I am concerned that the annual price increases will cost more on O2 than it would of on Virgin due to the way that the migration was handled.

As of the time of writing this review, one of our contracts has been canceled, and we're hoping it stays that way. Prior to this, my family had three contracts: one for myself, one for my dad, and one for my little brother. My dad and I had a generally positive experience with our contracts, with only occasional internet signal issues, which were infrequent and didn't significantly affect our overall satisfaction.Now, let's delve into the canceled contract concerning my little brother. Approximately two months ago, he temporarily lost his phone, but he managed to retrieve it the following day. On the day the phone was lost, we promptly contacted the service provider to report it and have the number barred. We were informed that we'd need to wait for 24 hours for the bar to be lifted, which we accepted. However, for the following three days, my brother couldn't make calls or use data. We reached out to customer support, only to be advised that switching SIM cards would be quicker. We visited the first store in Wembley, but my brother failed to answer the security questions and lacked the required identification, which, understandably, the store couldn't overlook.We then tried another store in Edgware while I was taking care of my car. We brought two forms of ID and proof of billing, and requested a new SIM card. However, we faced the same issue with security questions and ID verification. The system seemed to have a glitch in specifying which security question to answer. We contacted the service provider, and it turned out that my brother had two security questions and answers, and the system wasn't clear on which one to use. Despite answering correctly, the issue persisted.After trying to resolve the problem for several days, including obtaining multiple SIM cards and switching to different phones, we realized the problem wasn't with the SIM but likely linked to my brother's account. The service provider promised to investigate, but after a week, they requested another week to continue their inquiry. Keep in mind that we made repeated calls during this process, and sometimes the support team didn't have the necessary information, forcing us to provide it repeatedly.After waiting for over a month and a half with no resolution in sight, we decided to cancel the contract. Fortunately, we were given credit, so we didn't have to pay, but it became apparent that having a contract was pointless if we couldn't use the SIM. Interestingly, we switched to Giffgaff, which operates on the same network as our previous provider (O2), using the PAC code for our number, and everything worked perfectly. As such, I don't expect a cancellation bill, as I left the contract due to the absence of service, which should be evident in their records. It appears that my account was disabled at the time of writing this review.

Have bought new phone from 02 for my 02 service only contract. What a farce. Had to buy it via taking out other contract and then paying it off. Lad in shop was very precise about what I needed to do and even gave me script. I followed it to the letter luckily and noted down time, name of operative and transaction number. A month later they charged me ¬£600 for not using the contract. I phoned twice to try and get them to repay the amount and eventually had to get my bank to take the money back. Then they took it out again the next month because nobody it seems had made a note of the repayment. I've just had a third call. No manager in the office to speak to. They acknowledge I don't owe them the money but just don't seem to be able to get it together to stop taking it. Have been with them years because their coverage is good but this side of the business is totally chaotic, very badly organised and frankly leaves you feeling they couldn't give a damn.Update: On my bill for December it appears this problem is finally sorted. It took four telephone calls, an email and a visit back to the O2 shop where I bought the phone. One of the problems seems to be their billing service is automated and carries on sending out bills even when they adjust the amount in the account. A second problem is the telephone operatives are not authorised to adjust bills above a certain amount so they have to contact another department to authorise that and a third problem is that the supervisors are not numerous enough to deal with the volume of complaints so are not available to deal with you at the point of contact. To be fair, the humans I came in contact with were uniformly courteous. It appears to be the systems which require a radical rethink.

New contract with slow 4G and 3G speeds.I took out a new contract with the OnePlus 5T handset and had come from the EE network. The O2 network was very slow for 4G and 3G speeds. After I had contacted their customer services, they were unable to tell me why I was receiving slow speeds (2-10mbps) on 4G. I couldn't even load the Google Homepage, I might as well have had an old Nokia as the only thing my handset could do was make and receive phone calls.They allowed me to do one of the following;Send the handset back to them and pay for one months' airtime, ending my contractorPay the handset value off, which then can be unlocked for free and used on another network.I opted for the latter, paid ¬£438, and they unlocked my handset and ended my contract without penalty. I have switched back to EE, and back to the normal 50-60mbps 4G speeds.Their customer service team, particularly the technical support team aren't very good they told me that their phone masts were working correctly and that the network might be "busy" and when I complained regarding the slow speeds they made no effort to retain me as a customer and the retentions team processed my cancelation within minutes. Maybe they are aware of the slow speeds?To me, 4G speeds should be at a minimum of 30mbps, and just like home broadband packages now they should be regulated with a minimum guaranteed speed at your home address. I was lucky in this instance that O2 allow you to pay off your device and leave, but if it was over the 14 day cooling off period and I was with another provider then I would have been stuck in a 24 month contract with slow speeds. Hats off to O2 for resolving my issue and allowing me to leave my contract, I would return as a customer if they sort out the speed of their 4G services.

I don't know where to start. We've seen the worst possible customer service with over 8 hours on the phone to O2 in more than 30 calls. Please read this is you ever have problems reactivating your phone after reporting lost temporarily to O2.  They couldn't reverse the blocks they put on our phones.  It ended well in the end with 2 new phones provided free of charge - which is why the 3 star rating.- Loss of phone for a few hours result in device blacklisted.- Phone found shortly after. After 8 days and 8 hours of calls O2 still couldn't reverse what they had done to the phone even after removing the blacklist. As a result no signal, calls, imessage etc... the phone could only be used on WIFI.- To make worse O2 asked the sim to be put in someone else's phone to see if it worked. Doing this blacklisted their phone too and again when O2 reversed the process their Iphone was left unusable except via WIFI. Their phone was not on O2.- After much wrangling and refusals, O2 replaced the O2 contract handset with a new one via next day delivery but denied any responsibility for the ¬£1,100 + non O2 Iphone 12 Pro they had made unusable. Attempts were made to blame Apple and the carrier the phone was actually on.- We logged all calls (time, date, content etc..) ready to go to small claims court or ombudsman. The formal complaint process was initiated via email. An email was sent to the CEO (and a response from his team received within 24 hours), social media used and info sent a newspaper consumer champion.- Finally on the evening of 31st Jan we received a call from someone senior, professional and clued-up who wanted to help. After sending screen shots directly whilst on the call via email to them, a new un-locked Iphone 12 Pro at zero cost was promised via next day delivery.  The old phone will be returned in due course as part of the process.This non-O2 new replacement phone has just arrived as promised and with my old sim card I finally have a signal and working phone back. Thank you to who eventually sorted it out.

I have had T-Mobile 5G Home Internet for 11 months. It was traumatic to install and took many hours. The Gateway is a small corded box controlled by a mobile based app, just plug the box in and turn on. My T-Mobile tower is 1/2 mile from my house, my Gateway sits next to a window about 10-30 feet from my devices, a MacAir book, 3 ipads, 2 iphones, an Epson printer USB connected to the Air book, and an LG smart tv. The advertised download speed is true, between 100-400 bps.The app, once the complicated passwords are renamed, is easy to use.My connection shows 'Excellent' about 95% of the time. I assume that means the connection between the box and the tower. The connection between the devices and the gateway are sporadic. Two of the ipads, uncorded, disconnect at least five times during the day, the worst is the lost connection to the 'Air Printer' several times a week. What is strange the one ipad and the tv are 100% corded and never lose connection. I suspect sharing the tower with the T-Mobile cellphone users may be part of the problem. My few calls to customer service were helpful and quick. I have paperless auto pay and is no problem. I have not disconnected the gateway and moved it to another location in the town, so can't say how that would work out. I recommend the service, which has limited locations, for the convenience, price, and listed speed, Maybe you would not experience the disconnect problems I have, a nuisance, but easily fixed by 'forgetting the network' and reconnecting with the password, There is no contract so a tryout will be easy to give up if not satisfied.

Update:  hurray!!!  T-Mobile credited our mobile account $784.94!I posted a story on the company‚Äôs FB page with hashtag TMobile and their customer service page and my FB page. I have been a Sprint customer for 16 years and recently became notified via text message that I had to acquire a T-Mobile SIM card as they have merged. The options were to have the card shipped to me for $10 or to go to a store. I chose to go to a store to avoid the shipping costs and reduce the possibility of error. The closest store is about 30-40 miles from my home. I went to the store and was given the SIM to take home. The woman in the store told me how to do it and told me where to go to watch a video on the process. I asked her to do it for me, she would not, so I went home and watched the video to do it myself. **In small writing on one insert in the SIM card box, it states that you need to back up your voicemails or you will lose them. It does not say this in the video, and the woman in the store did not tell me. I did not notice and I lost all of my voicemails. That is not the purpose of my review though.** I put the SIM in my phone exactly as instructed, and my phone no longer worked. It would not connect to wifi. It would not connect to service. It was a locked and useless piece of technology. I used my landline phone to call customer service. I remained calm and tried to work with the agents to restore the use of my iPhone. The first agent attempted to assist me for 6 minutes before disconnecting me. I called back and got another agent that was especially kind. She attempted to help me for about 25 minutes before determining that she would not be able to assist me because I did not have a way to receive the one time code that she needed to send me in order to verify my account, and apparently my SIM card was faulty/did not exist. Because my phone didn't work, there was no way to receive the code to dive further in to this issue. We eventually found a way for me to receive the code, which was done by me emailing my mom from my laptop to ask her to receive the code and send it to me via email. She put me on hold to discuss with her team and then transferred me to another agent without telling me she was doing so. The new agent was not briefed on the situation so I got him caught up to speed and he attempted to help me for about 55 minutes, in the process, he guided me through phone resets that were unsuccessful in restoring the use of my phone, but they were successful in removing every setting, password, and face ID that were in my phone. He did not tell me that that would happen. At the time, I was just wanting to restore the use of my phone and wasn't even focused on the extent of what I had just lost. He disconnected me without warning. I called back and was connected with an agent that simply informed me that there was no way to help me and that I needed to travel back to a T-Mobile store and then disconnected me. I called back and was connected to an agent that assisted me for 47 minutes, ultimately resolving the initial problem and getting my phone activated to T-Mobile service. He also offered to send me a booster at no cost to increase service in my home. He discovered that there is only one T-Mobile tower in my area (there were 7 Spring towers) and that my service would be poorly effected by this switch. I was grateful for his help and his willingness to go above and beyond to help me with issues beyond what I was calling for. He was not able to help me restore my voicemails or my lost passwords/other information, but that is certainly not his fault. Every agent was pleasant, I had no personal issues with any of them, but they were not able/willing to help me and didn't seem to really care about the situation I was in. He thanked me for staying calm and kind and acknowledged how frustrated I must have felt. I would like to rate my last agent, Christian, every star in the world, because without him, T-Mobile would have lost a 16 year customer yesterday. I spent many hours of my day trying to do what they asked of me - not something I ever wanted - and it was a major inconvenience that caused a lot of stress. As far as I can tell, the only thing T-Mobile has done right is hire Christian. He deserves a lot of praise, and a raise. Christian, if you see this - please know how grateful I am. That is all, thanks.

Their customer service approach (teams with regional focus and follow-up to resolution) is far better than the past, and I had no reason to believe that would change according to inner reports from friends who are employees.In September of 2017 I noticed a drastic change in customer service policy/procedure - more calls to 611 than in the past were routed to overseas call centers who 1) had little ability/authority to resolve matters 2) struggled with the English language in their communication 3) couldn't relate to social and practical issues like addresses that directly affect US customers - all of which became more of a 'reading off a script' experience and endless cyclical talking that went nowhere.   In addition, any Twitter support through DirectMessaging was focused on hyper positivity, lofty rhetoric, exaggerated claims of expertise, and writing too much about themselves in an attempt to sympathize and empathize in obvious relatability - all which would be fine if accompanied with competence, accuracy, attention to detail, follow through, and a timely resolution. Because of these changes in customer service approach/policy, issues that formerly took days to a week to resolve now become lingering problems that last weeks to a month or more.I moved to a suburban/rural area that is still within a couple miles of a larger city, and according to antenna search/locator sites and an app called Network Cell Info Lite, there are several T-Mobile towers in my area, from 1/2 to 4 miles away with only one obstructed by geography (foothill). I never connect to the closest 4G tower, leading me to believe it's inactive or non-functioning. Doing drive tests with the diagnostic app reveal a very weak signal being br oadcast by most of the towers in the area, and even with full signal reception on phone (bars) the latency is very bad and data speeds are horrible and subpar - more akin to that of 3G or less.All of this information has been passed and communicated to TMobile over the past 4 weeks with little more than 'there are geographical difficulties' being reported from the engineers in the field.  This is only true of 1 out of the 6+ towers in the area.  I understand business decisions of cost vs benefit, and that unless/until a large customer base was complaining of problems they would delay or refrain from addressing such issues, but it seems there exists a lack of maintenance and ongoing upgrade concern/competence.  All the happy-talk virtue signaling in the world from customer service reps doesn't alter that.So I'm now experiencing what many others in 'less than adequate' coverage areas have experienced and the apparent changes in customer support have only exacerbated the frustration and unacceptable conditions.  This is my 2Cents.You can't trust their coverage map claims which are misleading, false, and blatantly full of errors.However, if you live in an area where towers are maintained and the signal is strong, their service is one of the best.  They really need to think through and work on their customer service approach - once again.**UPDATE 11/07/2017**After multiple attempts to contact a customer care or technical support person within the US by phone, I got lucky and reached a first level tech support person who transferred me to the 2nd level support. They took extensive notes and then created a ticket to be sent to engineers - meanwhile I created such an uproar on public Twitter messages that I was contacted by DirectMessage and they requested to call me directly to resolve the problem.During all of this, I continued to search for answers/solutions online. None of the support personnel directed or linked me to any T-Mobile online support documentation - but in my searches I found what I thought might be the problem. There was a detailed T-Mobile support document that did indeed provide some helpful information and could've been forwarded or linked or sent to me within the first day or two.Solution? The Personal Cellspot 4G LTE mini tower needed a complete 'reset', which can be accomplished by holding down the reset button on the back of the mini tower for 20+ seconds.  Up to this point, I had only tried 10 and 15 seconds as well as unplugging it for 30 minutes.  Once I did the 20+ second reset, the data speeds returned to a normal level (80-90mbits down, 30-45mbits up) and all was well.  I relayed all of this information - including the support documentation URL to T-Mobile support teams on Twitter and phone support and hopefully they will begin a process of searching for 'known issues' and FAQ's while assisting customers in order to actually resolve issues and to learn themselves in the process.

Knowing the cause [of the damage] is important in assessing if this might be a recurring event.‚Ä¢ Vodafone has limitations on Ofcom‚Äôs automatic compensation scheme, i.e. no payments for the first 48 hours of loss of service.‚Ä¢ Vodafone appear overly reliant on City Fibre with little influence regarding obtaining detailed communication, such as in this situation.‚Ä¢ City Fibre‚Äôs website claims of a reliable and consistent service, is debatable. On the occasion it drops though, router can take a very long time to regain a lost connection. Router is mediocre and app control is terrible... if you ever manage to set it up to your phone it chucks you out permanently at some point, and to reconnect the app you need to reset the router completely (even that didn't always work). Gave up on it.Again - OpenReach and many customer-facing telecom suppliers are doing it, but mid-contract, (over) inflationary rises in price is a dodgy practice in my eyes, however many companies there are that do it. If I sign up to a ¬£30, 24 month contract I should be paying ¬£30 in month 23, not ~¬£40. Else don't call it a contract - let customers leave whenever you change the terms (price).In all, absolutely no reason to stay at end of contract so will look to ditch and switch - as many services force you to nowadays - unless you want to sit paying more than you need to for being loyal/'lazy'.

Taken out a 2 year Broadband Service 500Mbs, changing over from BT 100Mbs service. Took about around half a day for the service to start but the VOIP transfer of the phone number from BT took somewhat longer. That doesn't surprise me and I wouldn't jump to conclusions the extra delay in down to Vodafone. Getting a mobile number transferred between operators  generally goes much more smoothly than transfer of landline numbers. I think it's a good deal at least for the contact period, even factoring in the ubiquitous April over inflation price increases that everyone applies.But whilst my phone number is now recognized the phone still doesn't work as they forgot to include a VOIP phone adapter in the equipment they sent me so they are having to now send through a  BS 6312 (BT) female to RJ11 male adapter separately. The order did include wired phone service  so I'm uncertain whether this omission was a mistake OR if they are just trying to penny pinch by excluding the adapter from the package. It's probably not a great idea to let people try to source their own VOIP adaptor, because there are various types with/without low pass filter and with/without ringing capacitor, and use of the wrong type could then lead to further issues.They did send superfluous adaptors for DSL which I don't need as I'm on Optical Fibre now and don't actually have a copper line any longer. In general I think they could save a bit of cost AND give a better service by matching up the equipment they send with the equipment needed for the order.The telephone  support for this problem was OK, but the link they sent via SMS for video call setup (so they could look at the connections on the back of the router) didn't work so well as the web page on the link  wouldn't let me grant permissions to use my smart phone camera whilst the ongoing phone call icon was still on screen in the foreground. So I had to drop the phone call first in order to grant permissions, and was then me on a video call for where I couldn't hear/see any one on the other end. It did the job though and I left the camera pointing at the back of the router and it became clear later that they had seen what they needed to see when they called me back (though the security questions all needed going through again). I've certainly had a lot worse support from other ISPs and was straight through to someone without waiting when I called them.The router they sent is a Technicolor THG3000. Comparable specs to the Sagecom built BT Smart Hub2 that I was using previously. Slightly more intuitive web user interface, I think. But still no 802.11ax (WiFi 6) or WPA3 security option. Would be nice to see movement from WiFi 5 as some operators are now gearing up to roll out routers with WiFi 7. I was hoping for a WiFi 6 based router, but not too surprised that I didn't get one.Update: The VoIP adapter arrived, but it still didn't have a ringing capacitor within it so everything worked apart from my phone not actually ringing when it's receiving a call. However I know the superfluous DSL filter I was sent will have a 1.0 - 1.8 uF capacitance across the 2 wire voice line side. So I connect the VOIP adapter to the router, the DSL filter to the VOIP adapter, and the phone to the voice side of the DSL filter and BINGO the phone now rings. Nothing like the diagram I was sent but it works. I have the advantage of having worked for GEC Plessey Telecoms in the past so I understood what a non ringing phone means and how to fix that. I fear that Vodafone don't understand any of it anymore because everything is outsourced in such a way that the left hand no longer knows what the right is doing and there is less and less technical expertise actually left in the company itself.

I've used Vodafone mobile for the last 15 years or so, never had a problem.Just switched to their broadband and my goodness what a joke.Appalling download speeds, well under their "guaranteed minimum", frequent disconnects across multiple devices, the inability to download updates/apps from the Google Play store on my phone - meaning using a VPN or mobile data to keep everything up to date, even YouTube struggles to load.3 stars overall due to the non-issue of my mobile, but 1 star for broadband.In hindsight I wouldn't switch if they were paying me.

Wow, I see that a lot of people are not happy with the price hikes. 10.5% CPI, 3.9% towards rolling out full fibre to more homes. I'm not even a full fibre customer so I will be paying this added cost so others receive a faster service. So in total, a 14.4% increase to me mid contract.Originally when I joined Vodafone, I was paying about ¬£19 a month for 55Mbs, with the latest increase, its closer to ¬£26.The price of my current plan is actually closer to what people are paying for full fibre, 500Mbs symmetrical download/upload. This means less value for me.I still have over a year of my contract left with Vodafone but it actually worked out cheaper for me to cancel it anyway and pay the cancellation fee.The cancellation fee is based on money that you would have paid Vodafone minus the costs that Vodafone have to pay as a result of you, being their customer. By this, I mean, they deduct tax, deduct line rental for however many months and then recalculate the tax based on the new amount.This meant that the cancellation fee for the remaining year of contract was about ¬£82.I then found a company called Lit that would do me full fibre, 500Mbs download, 500Mbs upload for ¬£27 a month.Based on me still being in a contract with Vodafone, they also offered me 6 months free service to cover the cost of my cancellation fee. They have also promised me that there will not be any mid contract price hikes.This means that I now have a new 24 month contract with the first 6 months free, followed by 18 payments of exactly ¬£27. Total for 24 months, including cancellation fee is ¬£568.Vodafone said they had a better deal as I wouldn't have to pay the cancellation fee and I wouldn't have to pay the 14.4% this April if I took out a new contract.They offered me 500Mbs download (250Mbs guaranteed) 68Mbs upload for ¬£30 a month. Taking into consideration that CPI will be added April 2024, I estimated that my bill would increase to ¬£35 a month for approximately 12 months. In total, it would have costed me ¬£780 to take another 24 month contract with Vodafone.I explained the numbers to the Vodafone advisor who still insisted that their deal was some how better. A lot of attention was focused on the cancellation fee that obviously I had already allowed for and factored in when comparing what was on offer.The advisor then proceeded to try and discredit Lit, saying they have never heard of them. I forwarded a link to their website. The advisor then said there wasn't any reviews, so I forwarded them a link to trustpilot where Lit score 4.9 out of 5. The advisor said that they didn't think I would get 6 months for free and to be careful incase it's a scam. They then said that the 6 months free is probably offered because they are a business that knows its going under. I explained it was to compensate people for the cancellation fee when switching mid contract. He then said that my contract will definitely still go up with Lit as all companies have to increase contracts based on CPI. I had to send a screenshot to the advisor to prove that Lit do not hike prices mid contract. This is also true for companies like Tescos mobile who also don't increase their prices.I feel like a lot of what I was being told wasn't strictly correct, so do be careful what you believe. The chat also went on for several hours despite me originally only contacting Vodafone to give my 30 days notice.I am, however, still suprised that Vodafone have a rating of 1.3 out of 5 on here. Despite my moan above, my service with Vodafone has been fantastic over the years that I've been with them. My speeds were always where they should have been and the service was very reliable with next to no drop outs. If there ever was a problem, Vodafone were quick to get it resolved.The low rating on here is quite harsh and not really a true reflection of them as a company. I would definitely consider moving back to Vodafone in the future if they have a good deal on.Unfortunately, being loyal to one company doesn't really work in the consumers favour and quite often results in prices continually increasing the longer you stay with them. As consumers, it is up to us to shop around for the best deals.

Today after 7 and a half years, I received my PAC code from Vodafone. I'm not going to write a dramatic 1 star review. My signal with Vodafone is generally strong and I've had no issues with customer services. But this company has consumer ethics problems.However, since COVID, the signal has not been as strong. I used to be the only person in my group of friends who used to get a signal at the football and now I'm not, it's as bad as the rest. So when I get e-mails telling me my prices are going up because of the cost of living, I expect to see my service being excellent. But unfortunately it went backwards.My bill has gone up and up and the cost of living raise was, I'm afraid, unfair, exploitative and the final straw and the reason I am leaving today. This is from the e-mail in March:"The monthly cost of your plan will go up from your April 2022 bill. As set out in the terms of your agreement with us, this increase is the UK Consumer Price Index (CPI) rate of 5.4% (as published in January 2022) to support the rise in our running costs and keep up with increased demand, plus an additional 3.9% to continue essential investment in our network as we expand coverage."This is frankly predatory and I will not support it. So I am off to Lebara - they use the Vodafone network and will charge me about a quarter of what I currently pay with a superior deal. I am sad to be leaving, I have been with Vodafone for the best part of 8 years. But the SIM only tariffs are no longer competitive, there was no real effort to keep my custom (not that I was ever going to stay) and I cannot emphasise enough how much I dislike that 3.9% rise. My coverage has got worse, not better, so previous rises are obviously not being spent wisely.In terms of coverage and overall experience, I have had few issues with Vodafone. In fact, they're pretty good. But the time has come to seek cheaper pastures elsewhere because a 9.3% rise when cost of living is out of control is predatory, exploitative and downright unfair.So you will get good coverage and friendly customer service experience, but you will pay for it and it will be outside of the amount you agreed to pay every month.Goodbye Vodafone. It's been fun.

A bit painful overall unfortunately, but the customer staff were as great as they could be.Saw a great offer online in March for Samsung S21 5G, Unlimited Max plan. With a guaranteed trade in of my S10e (subject to meeting conditions), ¬£44 per month (24 months). Great deal!Placed order Wed 31 Mar after 10.00pm, so too late for next day delivery. Fine. It's Easter weekend so can wait until the following Tues.Received email confirmation 22.31 for delivery on Tues 6 Apr. Nothing delivered.On inquiring, response was that the order was cancelled due to a 'technical issue'. No reason for error given, or why no follow up email to tell me. Passed around from initial complaints to upgrades to customer care, back to upgrades, etc.... Upshot - I can upgrade but only at today's (7 Apr) rates (which, shock, are not as generous); not the one I thought I signed up to (when I got my last phone, the following month the plan price went down. I had no recourse to ask for a better rate though...)Small print online states the contract only applies 'when the product is dispatched'. Not when you click that button to purchase. Not when you get the confirmation email. Not when you get it in your grubby little mitts. But only when dispatched. As such, it appears that if the courier loses it, or it is delayed... you are still liable to pay the prevailing rate (until found or proved stolen, I assume). If the order is cancelled by Vodafone (for any one of a number of reasons - or none, just a 'technical error'...), unlucky, no contract stands. The risk is transferred to you, my friends. Tell me I am wrong, Vodafone. Then I will show you your own terms and conditions.If you order online, get a confirmation and take a day off and get no email to say it is cancelled. Unlucky as no contract. And you cannot then ask for the original terms to be honoured as the 'deal is no longer available'. Those good old T&C.What was good was the attitude of all the customer support staff I engaged with. They got it. They listened. They were obviously limited by company policy. After putting in a formal (email) written complaint since the phone system just wasn't working, I got a response very quickly and the guy was great. The key thing was the confirmation email I received, that proved I had made the order - it was the only evidence as 'nothing was in the system' (don't delete those emails, folks). Complaint upheld in terms of cancellation made without my knowledge and no confirmatory email sent to me. Nonetheless, the 'technical issue' won through and those pesky terms and conditions (weighted in favour of the company) won out. Legally right; morally...?I have to comment I did go ahead with an upgrade, after being offered 25% discount on another monthly plan; it would be wrong not to disclose this. The deal was decent but not anywhere near as good as that which I thought I had committed to.In short. Customer service were actually really decent and I truly appreciate their attempts to help. But the company-level T&C element leaves the customer in a weak position if things go wrong. You takes your chance folks!

And as such, am able to stream live-TV using Mobile Hotspotting.However, those who take up the helm in the handling of customer queries (in particular, those higher up the ladder-of-ambition, snugly buckled into their Imperial Fleet seating arrangements), unfortunately do not seemingly have any business training, personable skills or sense of ethics under their belt to undertake such bouts and in doing so deliver way under an acceptable standard in these areas, whilst making efforts to conceal attempts at enforcing the dark-side.The company does as such:They advertise Unlimited Mobile services and yet the services are very much limited -1. Wildly fluctuating downloads speeds - down to minimal speeds (they do pick up as well; hence the two-star rating)2. Huge latency figures (a known issue)3. Bandwidth that is so narrow that one cannot make a phone-call and be on the internet at the same time4. Dystopian rule (we are not sons and daughters of their clon√®d regime)Personal experiences:When asking for a 'letter of deadlock' was told that a gratuity they had GIVEN and of which I made sure - in writing - was a gift-of-no-clauses, stated they would retrieve the fifty-pounds (already-banked) by force if I requested a 'letter of deadlock' in order to take the company up on the bandwidth issue.They came up with the resolution, to grant a piece of equipment that might help to widen the bandwidth and after I checked with their technical team as to whether this equipment would actually sort out the problem, and to which I received an affirmative, the offer was retracted, Vodafone continuing to refuse making satisfaction.Their advertising does not stipulate that Mobile Hotspotting will consist of poor performance but instead makes out that one is getting a super package for the price when in fact the amount is approaching the price for a broadband and phone deal that some (other) companies offer.I am fairly convinced that there is deliberate and secret capping of services as the company tries to push customers onto broadband deals instead of the monthly sim-deal accounts because line-broadband deals make more money, i.e:- instead of being an all-inclusive phone and internet deal, customers that are paying for a line-connection (with Vodafone) would have to pay equal to monthly mobile phone and internet prices for broadband-internet alone...plus...whatever else for a phone-line. Many-a-time told there would manifest some kind of resolution, advertising literature for broadband would instead be thrown at me.After having been kept in an online chat for about five to six hours, any ideas whatsoever as to some kind of resolution were voided, except for the (repeated) solution - not initially linked with this complaint - put forward in particular by those representing the company's CEO, to leave the contract free of charge.The problem comes down to the fact that these companies do not respect the duty in their hands to deliver a high standard of service because they do not value the technology that is in their hands at the outset - wrong people in the wrong jobs.Essentially, we are talking about professional advertising that masks back-street trading.

Not sure what happened to resolve this, apart from my frustration in having to chase this up myself, but I have increased this review from 2* to 3* as my complaint is now fully resolved; still - I shouldn't have had to complain in the first place (hence no higher rating!)

I signed up to a Vodafone plan through mobiles.co.uk because of a cashback offer on a high data allowance. My company also offers an employee discount on 12-mo Vodafone contracts. So I decided to give it a go.Vodafone have the best network in the UK. The Ofcom network coverage maps demonstrate it pretty well, and I did my own independent testing, and Vodafone came out on top in every place I've visited - 79% any coverage during my regular commute. I get fast speeds and general reliability is more stable than O2 and far superior to 3.There are many issues with Vodafone though:1. Some settings simply cannot be changed without getting in touch with customer service. For example, voicemail was completely inaccessible for months and only by "resetting" the voicemail was it resolved (not sure why it was not setup correctly in the first place, perhaps as I transferred numbers). Other settings also just show errors when trying to change them such as the age restriction bar.2. When changing limits and settings on the website or app, sometimes it ends up changing other settings unintentionally back to their defaults, or, the setting you actually changed reverts back (as if it never applied in the first place).3. Sometimes when trying to access the website just to get my bills, I'd just get an error saying come back later, which happened for a month - whereas the app was able to make changes without issue.4. If you sign up for a new contract with Vodafone with a new SIM card, even if your old contract has already ended, it takes 30 days to transfer your phone number to the new contract. Whereas moving the number to another provider would have taken at most a couple of days. I've managed to get it down to 7 days through threatening to leave, but this is still unacceptable.5. I previously wanted to leave shortly after my first contract ended, and I asked for my PAC code, and received comms about it many times, but never actually received the code. My online account was also unintentionally deleted so could no longer get to my bills or see my plan.6. When I cancelled a retention plan, the comms said I had to return my phone. The phone that I had actually bought myself and was not part of the contract. This is very misleading and other users could end up believing this.7. My experience of in-store staff is mixed - sometimes they were attentive and sometimes not. Though I don't blame this on the company per se.Overall, I'm very pleased with the coverage and data speed, on the fence about price changes, and not happy about customer service. I would be hesitant to recommend.

It has been quite some time since we have had BAD static on our 3 landline phones, even though we have cell phones as well.  I keep the landline phone because of hearing problems, and I have a machine that gives details when someone calls in to help, as well.  The static on our phone has been bad for 6 months or longer, and even people leaving messages on the landline phone, we could hear nothing of what they were saying, or even to call out on the phones. I decided after all this time that I have been paying the AT&T bill, we needed to find out why there was so much static on our phone all the time.  I made the call today, and within 30 minutes, Craig McMillin (I ask his name, but I'm not for sure of the correct spelling of the last name, but I believe he has worked for the company for several years) arrived, (I also received a text that he was on his way and the time period) after calling and confirming the correct address of where we lived. When arriving he told me his name and who he was with.  After telling him that we were having BAD static on all 3 landline phones, he went to each phone to check them out, etc. Then he run test on them. Even though he left some of them unplugged, he told me before he left, he would put everything back the way it was.  After checking the 3 landline phones, he could not find any problem, but the static was still there.  He checked outside of the house, and could see that the wires were leading to our "craw space" basement.  I really hated to have him look there, (we have had a lot of water in this area because of all the rain, and we have been trying to drain it out) but he told me he was checking "every" area, to try to "pinpoint" where the problem was.  To make the long story short, he FOUND the problem in our craw space, and was able to FIX the problem.  Craig was very personal and nice, and I would recommend him checking out anyone's problem, as he is very thorough!
